# Chapter Text

News feeds flooded every outlet across the globe:

**[BREAKING NEWS] The 22nd Great Demon Berith Has Fallen!**
*After an 81-day campaign through blood-soaked battlefields, the terror of Berith has ended. Leading the historic raid: Grid, Kraugel, and the Seven Dukes.*

**[EDITORIAL] A Debt the World Cannot Repay**
*Millions lost their homes when the Rotemon Kingdom fell. Without Grid and Kraugel uniting the Empire's dukes, Haken would have followed—another nation erased, countless players displaced. The economic value of their achievement alone...*

**[TACTICAL ANALYSIS] The Demon's Horrifying Resilience**
*Combat logs reveal Berith suffered thirteen separate amputations of his left arm. Nine each for his right arm and leg. Fifty-one fractures. Twenty-one critical wounds. Every injury regenerated instantly. Future encounters with high-ranking demons will require entirely new strategies...*

**[PLAYER'S CHOICE] Saintess Ruby Awarded Hidden First Place Merit**
*Her wide-area heal at the critical moment saved the raid. Ruby's intervention revitalized exhausted fighters when defeat seemed certain. Known for her charitable work, the Saintess proves herself a blessing to all humanity...*

**[SPECULATION] What Treasures Did They Claim?**
*The Overgeared Guild's legendary operational security holds firm—not a single leak. Still, this reporter can confidently estimate the top ten rewards exceed legendary-rated equipment in value. Grid's allies, the dukes, Kraugel, Zibal—all will emerge stronger than ever. Yet no jealousy mars their victory. The world celebrates them as heroes...*

**[EPIC UNVEILED] Grid's Story of Struggle**
*Through his epic, we glimpsed the hardships that forged him. Grid's difficult past is well-documented. Yet this reporter senses something more—with each chapter he writes, Grid's power will only grow...*

**[YOUTH SURVEY] Grid Named Top Role Model**
*Teenagers voted overwhelmingly: Grid is the person they most want to emulate. The same held true for respondents in their twenties and thirties. His annual growth, combined with his image as someone who conquered adversity, has captured the younger generation's imagination. Publishers are already compiling his achievements into books...*

**[IMMIGRATION SURGE] The Korean Dream**
*Applications for South Korean residency have skyrocketed. Many cite the Overgeared members who relocated as their inspiration...*

Every channel. Every newspaper. Youngwoo and Sehee's names blazed across headlines worldwide.

At home, their parents couldn't stop grinning.

"Did you see this article?" Youngwoo's mother waved a magazine. "We need to preserve these! Frame them!"

"Already done." His father's chest puffed with pride. "Bought twenty magazines. Well worth it."

"Twenty? Only twenty?" She fixed him with a stern look. "We should have a hundred—gifts for friends and relatives, keepsakes for grandchildren! How can Grid's father be so stingy?"

"I..." He cleared his throat sheepishly. "I actually ordered two hundred. They sold out. Backordered them all when the next printing runs."

"Oh!" Her expression melted. "You really are bold. The father of such accomplished children."

"And you're as wise as they are brilliant. Marrying you was the best decision of my life."

"Dear..."

"Honey..."

The air grew thick with affection.

Sehee smiled, watching her parents drift toward their bedroom. *They're going to make us a sibling at this rate.*

She remembered the darker days—when her brother drifted, and their parents blamed themselves for doubting him. They'd thrown themselves into work, determined not to burden their son. Their skin had tanned from endless hours under the sun. They'd seemed to age overnight.

But Sehee knew better. They were healthier than ever. Pride in their son transformed grueling labor into joyful exercise. When Youngwoo proved too busy, they donated and volunteered in his name. Each day, they grew happier. Stronger.

*All because of my brother.*

Sehee's chest tightened with admiration. *I want to be like him.*

Korea had produced greats before—legendary comedians, athletes, artists. But those were rare. Once-in-a-generation phenomena. And never a gamer. Five years after Satisfy's launch, one player had changed the world's entire perception of gaming.

*The game... honor... my parents... success through gaming...*

Her thoughts churned. Her generation had been raised on a single mantra: *Education is the path to success.* But now? With Satisfy dominating the world, was studying the only answer?

Her brother proved otherwise.

The life she'd always imagined—a stable job, wealth enough to support her family—could be achieved through Satisfy. After serious contemplation, Sehee made her decision.

She tapped her smartwatch, fingers dancing across the holographic keyboard. The message went to her best friend Yerim:

*Should we take a leave of absence from school? Level up instead?*

The reply came instantly:

*ㅇㅅㅇ/ YES.*

"..."

Had Sehee been the only one hesitating? Was she inflexible? *Is that why I don't like Jishuka—because she's too open?*

Another message arrived:

*Let's get those older women away from your brother! >_<*

Sehee knew exactly who Yerim meant. Yura, who'd confessed publicly. Jishuka, who'd moved next door and launched a daily campaign of seduction. Yerim's territorial instincts were on high alert.

Sehee sighed. She loved Yerim dearly, but as a sister-in-law? *Brother would suffer too much.*

*Oh, running late today. New boyfriend. Date night! ★*

Sehee stared at the screen. *Three boyfriends this month. Three.*

Yerim was wonderful—free-spirited, passionate, alive. But her brother needed stability.

Mental note: *Yerim—eliminated.*

***

In Reinhardt, capital of the Overgeared Kingdom, Grid finally allowed himself to rest.

He strolled through gardens with Irene and Lord. Shared meals. Drank tea on sun-dappled terraces. Simple pleasures he'd denied himself for too long. Irene was older than him now in years, yet remained achingly beautiful—would remain beautiful all her life.

*This is what matters.*

Maybe he should retire. Spend his days like this forever. The thought surfaced as he watched Irene's delighted smile, and guilt stabbed through him. *I'm never here for her.*

Her pale fingers poked his cheek. "Don't think like that. No matter where you are, I feel you. I'm never lonely."

"Irene..."

She read him so effortlessly. A woman who always put him first. Her presence was a blessing he'd never deserved. Grid pulled her into his arms.

Irene laughed softly against his chest. "Besides, what's that old saying? As long as a husband earns well, it's fine if he's rarely home..."

"What?" Grid jerked back. "Who told you that?"

Pure innocence shone in her smile. "Yerim."

"..."

"I listened to her advice and observed other wives. The ones whose husbands are home constantly? They quarrel. Isn't that sadder? A little distance between couples seems healthy."

"..."

*Yerim corrupted my pure wife.*

Grid wanted to cry. But he recognized the thoughtfulness behind Irene's words—she was trying to ease his guilt.

"When things settle with the Empire," he said softly, "let's take a trip. Just us. That beautiful coastline you love."

"I can't wait." Irene kissed his cheek, her heart overflowing. Her husband—a commoner who'd become a noble, founded a kingdom, and now sought friendship with the Empire itself. How blessed she was to have met him. She offered silent gratitude to every god who'd guided their paths together.

Meanwhile...

Lord watched his parents embrace from a respectful distance, giggling quietly. The young prince had learned a vital lesson from their example: love was the most beautiful connection in existence.

He turned and kissed one of the Rebecca's Daughters standing beside him. As he did every day.

Coke, his sworn knight, shook his head. *His lips never chap despite doing that constantly.*

Honestly, Coke envied the prince's harem. But he also saw the strategic value. If Grid's grandchildren numbered in the dozens—or hundreds—the kingdom's future was unshakeable.

*One or two hundred third-generation Grids...*

The future looked overwhelming in the best possible way.

***

Late that night, a cool breeze stirred the palace terraces.

Grid stepped outside after ensuring Irene slept soundly. He addressed the empty darkness: "Well?"

A voice answered from nothing. "We can't build friendship through one-sided gestures. When the Overgeared Kingdom and the Empire establish formal relations, I'll come forward for treatment."

"Stubborn bastard."

During the return journey, Grid had remembered his promise to heal Grenhal's wounds. In his excitement over the successful raid, he'd forgotten entirely. He'd sent Faker to bring Grenhal to him immediately.

This was the duke's response. He'd wait for a better future—when politics aligned with personal need. Inflexible, perhaps. But trustworthy.

*I really was lucky.*

Grenhal. Morse. Basara. Gaining relationships with those three dukes was fortune beyond measure. And it had all started with listening to Lauel—prioritizing the Ruins of the War God over other concerns.

*Following Lauel's advice is like getting bread while I sleep.*

Grid smiled and returned to bed.

***

Simultaneously, in Titan, capital of the Saharan Empire...

*His Majesty left the palace personally? That's unusual.*

Duke Grenhal had returned from the Berith raid and requested an imperial audience, only to be told to wait ten days. The Emperor had departed on urgent business. Quite irregular. Grenhal felt both puzzled and pleased—at least the Emperor was handling state affairs actively. He'd retired to his Titan villa to wait.

Then the riders appeared. Magic machines surrounded his estate.

"Duke Grenhal." Fourth Prince Edan's voice was cold. "I'm placing you under arrest for treason."

"Perhaps you'd care to elaborate on these charges?"

"We'll discuss details in prison."

"An imperial prince lacks authority to detain a duke."

"I lack authority." Edan's smile was razor-thin. "But I have strength."

"..."

The prince had committed fully. Grenhal stepped back warily. The magic machines he'd witnessed in the canyon exceeded his expectations—caution was vital. But Edan pressed forward.

"Take this seriously." Edan signaled the riders. Their magic machines flared with multicolored light.

Grenhal's berserker power erupted in response.
